title: Mama Comba’s Gombeaux
description: In Africans in Colonial Louisiana, Dr. Gwendolyn Midlo Hall argues this document offers the first Gulf Coast reference to gumbo (“un Gombeau”) in the archive. This is the testimony of Mama 'Julie' Comba
subject: a fifty year old negresse and African woman [nation Mandinga] who lived in the Hospital for the Poor [Hospital de Pauvres] and was enslaved to the Capuchin priests. Mama Comba appears before the French Superior Council in this
latitude: as a result of the arrest of two runaways
source: and the nègre Louis also called Foy (dit Foy). The runaways were caught and accused of murder
identifier: but ultimately charged with public drunkenness
type: theft and firing weapons into the air (no one was killed) and with being fugitives. Mama Comba was interrogated because she hosted a feast that Cezar and Louis were guests at
format: bringing with them a pig that Louis allegedly stole and that the guests all took part in cooking and eating. The document below is drawn from part of Mama Comba’s testimony."
